Description:: Aphanitic extrusive igneous rock formed from the rapid cooling of low-viscosity lava rich in magnesium and iron. calcic plagioclase feldspar and pyroxene. Olivine can also be a significant constituent. Black/grey.
Coarse-grained (phaneritic) intrusive igneous rock composed mostly of quartz, alkali feldspar, and plagioclase. Pink/white/grey with black and clear/white.
Coarse-grained clastic (fragments) sedimentary rock; Pebbles >2mm in size; set in a fine-grained matrix of sand; silt; commonly cemented with CaCO3; iron oxide; SiO2; or hardened clay
Sedimentary rock with 50% or more CaCO3. Usually white; grey; tan, can have accessory minerals like fluorite, quartz, pyrite, etc.
Fine-grained detrital sedimentary rock; consolidation of clay; silt; mud; breaks readily into thin layers; red; brown; black; or grey

intermediate type between silica-poor basalt and silica-rich rhyolite. It is fine-grained (aphanitic) to porphyritic in texture, and is composed predominantly of sodium-rich plagioclase plus pyroxene or hornblende. Black/white/grey.

hard, fine-grained sedimentary rock composed of microcrystalline or cryptocrystalline quartz. most often manifests as gray, brown, grayish brown and light green to rusty red[9][10] (occasionally dark green). Usually banded.

clastic sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-sized (0.0625 to 2 mm) silicate grains. Sandstones comprise about 20â€“25% of all sedimentary rocks.[1] Most sandstone is composed of quartz or feldspar. Red/orange/tan/white.
Iron-rich sedimentary rock; hard; coarsely banded or non-banded; and non-cherty

Minerals:: Quartz; Plagioclase; K-feldspar; Talc; Muscovite; Biotite; Chlorite
Description:: Clastic sedimentary rock that is composed mostly of silt. It is a form of mudrock with a low clay mineral content, which can be distinguished from shale by its lack of fissility. Tan/grey.
Glassy; highly vesicular; mostly silicic igneous rocks. White.

Fine-grained, foliated, homogeneous metamorphic rock derived from an original shale-type sedimentary rock composed of clay or volcanic ash through low-grade regional metamorphism. It is the finest grained foliated metamorphic rock. Grey.

Minerals:: Quartz; Plagioclase; K-feldspar; Talc; Muscovite; Biotite; Chlorite; Hornblende
Description:: Gneiss nearly always shows a banded texture characterized by alternating darker and lighter colored bands and without a distinct cleavage.
Marble is a metamorphic rock composed of recrystallized carbonate minerals, most commonly calcite or dolomite. Marble is typically not foliated, although there are exceptions. Mostly white.

Minerals:: Quartz; Talc; Muscovite; Biotite; Chlorite; Hornblende
Description:: medium-grained metamorphic rock showing pronounced schistosity. This texture reflects a high content of platy minerals, such as micas, talc, chlorite, or graphite. These are often interleaved with more granular minerals, such as feldspar or quartz. Grey/black/white.

Diorite is an intrusive igneous rock composed principally of the silicate minerals plagioclase feldspar (typically andesine), biotite, hornblende, and sometimes pyroxene. The chemical composition of diorite is intermediate, between that of mafic gabbro and felsic granite.[3][4] It is distinguished from gabbro on the basis of the composition of the plagioclase species; the plagioclase in diorite is richer in sodium and poorer in calcium.

It is generally glassy or fine-grained (aphanitic) in texture, but may be porphyritic, containing larger mineral crystals (phenocrysts) in an otherwise fine-grained groundmass. The mineral assemblage is predominantly quartz, sanidine, and plagioclase. It is the extrusive equivalent to granite
A fine to medium-grained metamorphic rock characterised by a strong foliation and is lustrous; intermediate in grade between slate and schist
Metamorphosed quartz-sandstone (metaquartzite) or unmetamorphosed sandstone; consisting chiefly of quartz grains that are so completely cemented with secondary silica (orthoquartzite). White color

Minerals:: Quartz; Muscovite; Biotite; Chlorite; Plagioclase; K-feldspar; Smectite; Illite; Goethite
Description:: Fine-grained sedimentary rock whose original constituents were clays or muds. Mudstone is distinguished from shale by its lack of fissility
Highly vesicular; basaltic glass, darker than pumice.
Dacite is a fine-grained igneous rock that is normally light in color. It is often porphyritic.

A coarse-grained clastic rock; composed of angular broken rock fragments held together by a mineral cement or in a fine-grained matrix; it differs from conglomerate in that the fragments have sharp edges and unworn corners.
A rock composed of one or more serpentine group minerals formed by serpentinization (hydration and metamorphic transformation) of rock consisting almost wholly of ferromagnesian silicate minerals
Gabbro is a coarse-grained, dark-colored, intrusive igneous rock. It is usually black or dark green in color and composed mainly of the minerals plagioclase and augite.
Dense, coarse-grained igneous rock consisting mostly of the silicate minerals olivine and pyroxene. Peridotite is ultramafic, as the rock contains less than 45% silica. Dark green/grey.
Dark-coloured, heavy, often altered and brecciated (fragmented), intrusive igneous rock that contains diamonds in its rock matrix.
Group of rocks with mainly of amphibole and plagioclase, and little or no quartz. It is typically dark-colored and dense, with a weakly foliated or schistose (flaky) structure
Mineral with a vitreous luster; three perfect cleavage planes; and a common rhombohedral form. It is often white or clear in color
Very common mineral with vitreous luster; no cleavage; and many colors; commonly white or clear. It's most common form is a hexagonal prism; but it can be amorphous
Mineral with a vitreous to earthy luster; one cleavage plane; and a common octahedral form. It has many colors.

medium- to coarse-grained rock that is among the most abundant intrusive igneous rocks. It has quartz and is distinguished from granite by its having more plagioclase than orthoclase. Grey/white with black specks.

Group of extrusive igneous rocks (lavas) that are rich in nepheline and potash feldspar. The typical phonolite is a fine-grained, compact igneous rock that splits into thin, tough plates. Grey/white/black color.

Soft form of limestone that is not well cemented and thus is often powdery and brittle. It usually ranges in color from white to light gray to buff and forms from sediment deposited in a saltwater environment.
Fine-grained sedimentary rock composed primarily of dolomite, a calcium and magnesium carbonate mineral. Dolostone is similar to limestone. White/grey color.

Minerals:: Quartz; Plagioclase; Muscovite; Biotite; Illite; Smectite
Description:: Variety of sandstone generally characterized by its hardness, dark color, and poorly sorted angular grains of quartz, feldspar, and small rock fragments or lithic fragments set in a compact, clay-fine matrix.
